newsitem.title: USA: Burnett in running for another airline account.
newsitem.headline: Burnett in running for another airline account.

text.p: Leo Burnett Co., the advertising giant which two months ago lost its longtime client United Airlines in a bitter agency shootout, is now in the running for another major airline's marketing business.

Delta Air Lines put its estimated $100 million advertising account, held by Omnicom's BBDO for 51 years, up for review Tuesday just four weeks after former United Airlines marketing executive Gayle Bock joined

The scenario is hauntingly familiar to the plight of Leo Burnett Co., which lost the United Airlines business in a split decision with Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, and Young & Rubicam, New York, in October. The $120 million assignment followed a knock-down, drag-out ad review that also left TBWA Chiat/Day in the dust.

Burnett, creator of United's "Come fly our friendly skies" theme and the airline's trademark use of Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue, had a 31-year flight with United Airlines, a unit of Chicago-based UAL Corp.

As with the Delta contest, the United review followed a change in the marketing department -- the appointment of Michael Howe as director-advertising and promotion, after the retirement in June of John Ruhaak, United's vice president-advertising and promotion for 22 years and a former Burnett veteran.

Now, the tables may be turning for Burnett, which among a host of other agencies, including BBDO, WPP Plc's Ogilvy & Mather, Interpublic Group's Ammirati Puris; N.W. Ayer, Wieden & Kennedy; Cordiant Plc's Bates USA; Messner Vetere; Hal Riney & Partners and WPP's J. Walter Thompson Co., is in contention for the account.

Erin Flynn, Delta's manager of corporate communications, said the only restrictions for the review were that a participating agency didn't have competing airline business, had the capability to handle global business and had a presence in Atlanta.
Burnett, which has an office in Atlanta servicing Coca-Cola Co.'s Fruitopia and Minute-Maid accounts, made a vow when it lost the United business not to let the agency's airline know-how go to waste.
